questionData.context: Your friend has just got a place at their dream university. You want to respond warmly.
questionData.question: Write an email to a friend congratulating them on getting a place at their dream university.

items.text: say why you're happy for them

Hey!

I just heard your amazing news! Congratulations on getting into your dream university! I'm absolutely thrilled for you.

Main Details

You've worked so hard for this and you totally deserve it. I remember all those late nights you spent studying and stressing about the application, so I'm really happy it's all paid off. When do you actually start? And have you sorted out where you're going to live yet? I bet you're both excited and a bit nervous about the whole thing.

Action / Request

We need to celebrate properly! How about we go out for dinner this weekend? Or if you'd prefer something more low-key, we could just grab some drinks and have a catch-up. Whatever you fancy really, it's your choice. Just let me know what works for you and we'll sort something out.

Closing

So proud of you! Can't wait to celebrate.

Lots of love,

questionData.context: Your friend is nervous about studying abroad. You want to reassure them and give helpful advice.
questionData.question: Write an email to a friend who is nervous about studying abroad, giving advice and reassurance.
keyPoints: Reassure them and normalise their nerves
Give practical advice for the first weeks
Suggest how to prepare before leaving

items.text: say it's normal to feel nervous
first weeks: routines, meeting people, admin
plan how to stay in touch

styles.default:
Opening

Hi!

I got your message and I just wanted to say it's completely normal to feel nervous about going abroad. Honestly, everyone feels like that before a big move.

Main Details

For the first few weeks, try to establish some sort of routine as quickly as you can ‚Äì it really helps you settle in. Make an effort to talk to people in your classes even if it feels awkward at first, and definitely join at least one club or society because that's the easiest way to make friends. Don't worry if you feel a bit lost initially, everyone does and it gets easier pretty fast.

Before you leave, make sure you've got all your important documents sorted and keep copies of everything. Pack some home comforts like photos or favourite snacks. Try to learn a few basic phrases if you're going somewhere with a different language. And work out how you're going to stay in touch with family and friends back home.

Action / Request

You're going to have an amazing time, I promise. If you need to chat about anything just message me anytime.

Closing

Good luck! You've got this.

Love,
[Your Name]
styles.alternative1:
Opening

Hey!

Don't worry about feeling anxious ‚Äì literally everyone feels that way before studying abroad. It's a big step but you'll be absolutely fine.

Main Details

When you first get there, focus on practical stuff like registering at the university, opening a bank account, and finding your way around campus. These small tasks will help you feel more in control. Try to be friendly and chat to people whenever you can ‚Äì your classmates are probably feeling just as nervous as you are. Sign up for activities or sports clubs straight away because waiting makes it harder to join later.

Preparation-wise, sort out all your paperwork well in advance so you're not stressed last minute. Take things from home that make you feel comfortable. Do some research about the area you're moving to. And set up ways to video call home regularly so you don't feel too homesick.

Action / Request

This is going to be such a great experience for you. Keep me updated on how it goes!

Closing

You'll do brilliantly!

Take care,
[Your Name]
styles.alternative2:
Opening

Hi there!

I can totally understand why you're nervous but honestly you're going to be fine. It's natural to feel apprehensive about something new and unfamiliar.

Main Details

In those early days, get yourself into a good daily routine with regular meal times and sleep patterns ‚Äì it sounds boring but it genuinely helps. Push yourself to introduce yourself to people and accept invitations even when you don't really feel like it. Look for student groups that match your interests because shared activities make forming friendships much easier. Remember that feeling overwhelmed at the start is completely normal and temporary.

As far as preparation goes, check you have everything you need document-wise and make backup copies. Pack some familiar items to make your room feel homely. Find out what you can about the city and the university beforehand. And think about how you'll maintain contact with people here.

Action / Request

This is such an exciting opportunity. Drop me a message whenever you need to talk.

Closing

Best of luck!

Speak soon,
